Description: Egyptian terracotta female figure. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of white (gypsum?) coating, covering a red slip. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. Similar to Naukratis example in Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology (NA715, see also NA712) that Gutch dated to between 150BC and 250AD (Gutch in Hogarth 1899, pl.12, no.167), though a similar figure was dated to the mid or late 3rd century BC (Fischer 1994, pl.8, no.54; see also pl.24), others to the late Ptolemaic or Roman Periods (Bayer-Niemeier 1988, pl. 94.7-5.8, nos 538, 539). Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.456) (Phase 1)
